newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY '96 GDP FIGURE NOT SEEN CHANGING FORECASTS.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY '96 GDP FIGURE NOT SEEN CHANGING FORECASTS.

text.p: The one percent figure of
Hungary's gross domestic product (GDP) growth in 1996, released
on Friday, was slightly above expectations but would not lead
to a change in forecasts for 1997, analysts said on Monday.
The Central Statistical Office (KSH) said that Hungary's
GDP increased by one percent in 1996, compared with 1.5 percent
in 1995, according to preliminary figures.
Household consumption and investments both dropped by three
percent last year, while exports rose 10 percent and imports
increased seven percent, the KSH said.
This was the fourth time that the KSH released preliminary
quarterly GDP figures, testing a new method of calculations.
Budapest Bank chief analyst Peter Bihari said the figures
for 1996 were better than expected.
Budapest Bank's forecast for the 1996 GDP growth was 0.5
percent, while they said household consumption was likely to
drop by four percent and investments by 4.4 percent.
But the difference was not large enough to trigger
far-reaching conclusions, and the bank was not likely to change
its forecast of 1.5 to three percent for 1997 GDP growth.
"(The difference) is within the error margin," he said.
"These figures were calculated according to an experimental
method and I guess they will be corrected downward.
GKI Economic Research Judit Barta also said the KSH figures
were likely to be modified in the future, however she added
that the figures caused some surprise to GKI.
"(The GDP growth figure) is pleasing as we projected
stagnation on the basis of figures released so far," she said.
"In the second half of last year there must have been quite
good growth, to produce that average figure."
The KSH said the GDP grew by three percent year-on-year in
the fourth quarter of 1996, compared with one percent in the
third quarter and stagnation in the first half of the year.
Household consumption continued to drop in the third and
fourth quarters, while investments already rose by six percent
year-on-year in the last three months of 1996, compared with
three percent decline in the third quarter.
Higher GDP growth figures for the second half of 1996,
taken as a basis of year-on-year GDP calculations this year,
may lead to slowing growth rates in the second two quarters of
1997, Barta added.
"It may happen that GDP growth will be quick in the first
half, and somewhat slower in the second," she said.
She added that the fresh KSH figures were unlikely to
encourage GKI to change its forecast for 1997.
"We continue to expect 2.5 to three percent GDP growth,"
she said.
GDP figures released by the KSH on Friday following:
HUNGARY 1996 GDP Q4 Q3 Q2 Q1 1996
Household
consumption -3 -2 -2 -3 -3
Investments +6 -3 -15 -11 -3
Products/services
Y/Y pct change +3 +1 0 0 +1
-- Budapest newsroom (36 1) 327 4040
